description: FITCHBURG- The Fitchburg Art Museum has hosted Art in Bloom every spring for 22 years, and although this year's in-person event was canceled in consideration of the health and safety of the museum's guests, volunteers, and staff, the online floral challenge which was created was a great success. This popular event invites local floral designers, garden clubs, and...
text:
FITCHBURG - The Fitchburg Art Museum has hosted Art in Bloom every spring for
22 years, and although this year's in-person event was canceled in
consideration of the health and safety of the museum's guests, volunteers, and
staff, the online floral challenge which was created was a great success.

This popular event invites local floral designers, garden clubs, and community
members to interpret the art in Fitchburg Art Museum's galleries with flower
arrangements.

"We are excited to say that the Art in Bloom: An Online Floral Challenge was a
huge success," Vanessa De Zorzi, museum marketing manager, said. "It was truly
a community event and a FAM team effort. We received a large number of
creative responses covering a wide variety of media from floral arrangements,
to culinary arts, photography, digital drawing, found object sculpture, and
more."

The Fitchburg Art Museum staff had a lot of fun creating and putting together
Art in Bloom: An Online Floral Challenge.

"I thought why not make Art in Bloom something people can participate in from
home," Jessie Olson, the museum's membership and events manager, said. "People
may have flowers blooming in their yards. Or if not, we encouraged people to
make flowers materials they can find in their house."

"We chose categories that represented the variety of interpretations and
materials, that would not only celebrate the imagination and creativity, but
also the fun of the process," Olson said.

Winners of the floral challenge were selected by community jurors including
Tamar Russell Brown of Sitka Creations, David Ginisi of the N.C. Mass. Chamber
of Commerce, Jessica Clarke local artist and McKay Arts Academy teacher, and
Julie K. Gray, theartist featured in the Fitchburg Art Museum exhibition After
Spiritualism: Loss and Transcendence in Contemporary Art.

"It is important to see how we are still able to bring art into people's
lives, even when they are unable to walk through our galleries," Olson said.
"The museum's mission is to be a catalyst for creativity, learning and
community. This was an opportunity for our community to not only learn about
the art in our collection but demonstrate their own creativity in response to
it."

Art in Bloom is held during the month of April at the museum and is
enthusiastically partnered with the Laurelwood Garden Club and is the museum's
busiest weekend of the year, a time when families and friends have a day at
the museum.

"Art in Bloom is our most popular event of the year," Olson added. "We wanted
our public to still enjoy the idea of art and flowers, even if it was from
afar."

Several interpreters expressed appreciation that they were able to still enjoy
this event, but also that the chance to make art at home gave them something
positive and colorful to think about.

"They had fun," Olson said. "And that is the most important thing to me - that
people think of museums and fun together."

The Fitchburg Art Museum is grateful for your support and looks forward to
welcoming the community back to their galleries and public spaces. Even in
these uncertain times, their mission is to inspire the miracle of art, she
said.

The online event closed with a champagne reception celebration video.

"Museum staff, docents and community members joined in a special conversation
about this year's Art in Bloom," De Zorzi said. "We discussed how we put the
event together, what inspired us, what we enjoyed most, and announced the
challenge winners.

The video premiered on May 15 and is now live on Fitchburg Art Museum's
website for all to enjoy.

"The world is changing. I grieve the loss of some things that will never be
the same, but I am excited for the challenge of connecting with our audiences
and members in new ways ~ in some ways - it is more interactive and more
inventive," Olson said. "By nature, art is a response to the world in which it
is created. So, it stands to reason that art museums are also responding to
the world and community and what they are going through right now. I like that
it makes us not only relevant, but an antidote to some of the more difficult
parts of our present."

Art in Bloom Winners include:

Most Creative Container: Maxwell Zaleski's interpretation of Douglas
Kornfeld's "Thurston," 2015

Best Use of Nature: Sue Cunio Salem's interpretation of Winslow Homer's
"Waiting for a Bite," 1874

Best Composition: Cynthia Robinson's interpretation of Winslow Homer's
"Waiting for a Bite," 1874

Most Illusionistic: Maxwell Zaleski's interpretation of Anne Lilly's "To Be,"
2016

Punniest: Jane Fulton Suri's interpretation of Scott Prior's "Sunflowers at
Sunrise," 2015

Best Use of Found Objects: Victoria Brier's interpretation of Julie K. Gray's
"Postmortem: Margaret," 2019

Most Inventive Materials: Julie Palioca's interpretation of Jo Sandman's
"Serpent 1," 20122014

Best Use of Color: Carolyn Quirk's interpretation of Maria Molteni's "Bough
House / Bauhaus," 20192020

The community can get inspired by viewing the artwork of Art in Bloom. The
full gallery of creative submissions can be viewed on Flickr, as well as the
gallery of category winners.

Also, explore the artwork of community groups the Material Girls Quilt Guild
and students of McKay Arts Academy inspired by the Art in Bloom event and the
spirit of spring.

For more information, please e-mail Membership and Events Manager, Jessie
Olson at [events@fitchburgartmuseum.org](mailto:events@fitchburgartmuseum.org)
and be sure to visit their website at
[www.fitchburgartmuseum.org](http://www.fitchburgartmuseum.org)

title: Fitchburg Art Museum's 'Art in Bloom' virtual contest winners announced
html:
FITCHBURG - The Fitchburg Art Museum has hosted Art in Bloom every spring for 22 years, and although this year's in-person event was canceled in consideration of the health and safety of the museum's guests, volunteers, and staff, the online floral challenge which was created was a great success.

This popular event invites local floral designers, garden clubs, and community members to interpret the art in Fitchburg Art Museum's galleries with flower arrangements.

"We are excited to say that the Art in Bloom: An Online Floral Challenge was a huge success," Vanessa De Zorzi, museum marketing manager, said. "It was truly a community event and a FAM team effort. We received a large number of creative responses covering a wide variety of media from floral arrangements, to culinary arts, photography, digital drawing, found object sculpture, and more."

The Fitchburg Art Museum staff had a lot of fun creating and putting together Art in Bloom: An Online Floral Challenge.

"I thought why not make Art in Bloom something people can participate in from home," Jessie Olson, the museum's membership and events manager, said. "People may have flowers blooming in their yards. Or if not, we encouraged people to make flowers materials they can find in their house."

"We chose categories that represented the variety of interpretations and materials, that would not only celebrate the imagination and creativity, but also the fun of the process," Olson said.

Winners of the floral challenge were selected by community jurors including Tamar Russell Brown of Sitka Creations, David Ginisi of the N.C. Mass. Chamber of Commerce, Jessica Clarke local artist and McKay Arts Academy teacher, and Julie K. Gray, theartist featured in the Fitchburg Art Museum exhibition After Spiritualism: Loss and Transcendence in Contemporary Art.

"It is important to see how we are still able to bring art into people's lives, even when they are unable to walk through our galleries," Olson said. "The museum's mission is to be a catalyst for creativity, learning and community. This was an opportunity for our community to not only learn about the art in our collection but demonstrate their own creativity in response to it."

Art in Bloom is held during the month of April at the museum and is enthusiastically partnered with the Laurelwood Garden Club and is the museum's busiest weekend of the year, a time when families and friends have a day at the museum.

"Art in Bloom is our most popular event of the year," Olson added. "We wanted our public to still enjoy the idea of art and flowers, even if it was from afar."

Several interpreters expressed appreciation that they were able to still enjoy this event, but also that the chance to make art at home gave them something positive and colorful to think about.

"They had fun," Olson said. "And that is the most important thing to me - that people think of museums and fun together."

The Fitchburg Art Museum is grateful for your support and looks forward to welcoming the community back to their galleries and public spaces. Even in these uncertain times, their mission is to inspire the miracle of art, she said.

The online event closed with a champagne reception celebration video.

"Museum staff, docents and community members joined in a special conversation about this year's Art in Bloom," De Zorzi said. "We discussed how we put the event together, what inspired us, what we enjoyed most, and announced the challenge winners.

The video premiered on May 15 and is now live on Fitchburg Art Museum's website for all to enjoy.

"The world is changing. I grieve the loss of some things that will never be the same, but I am excited for the challenge of connecting with our audiences and members in new ways ~ in some ways - it is more interactive and more inventive," Olson said. "By nature, art is a response to the world in which it is created. So, it stands to reason that art museums are also responding to the world and community and what they are going through right now. I like that it makes us not only relevant, but an antidote to some of the more difficult parts of our present."

Art in Bloom Winners include:

Most Creative Container: Maxwell Zaleski's interpretation of Douglas Kornfeld's "Thurston," 2015

Best Use of Nature: Sue Cunio Salem's interpretation of Winslow Homer's "Waiting for a Bite," 1874

Best Composition: Cynthia Robinson's interpretation of Winslow Homer's "Waiting for a Bite," 1874

Most Illusionistic: Maxwell Zaleski's interpretation of Anne Lilly's "To Be," 2016

Punniest: Jane Fulton Suri's interpretation of Scott Prior's "Sunflowers at Sunrise," 2015

Best Use of Found Objects: Victoria Brier's interpretation of Julie K. Gray's "Postmortem: Margaret," 2019

Most Inventive Materials: Julie Palioca's interpretation of Jo Sandman's "Serpent 1," 2012–2014

Best Use of Color: Carolyn Quirk's interpretation of Maria Molteni's "Bough House / Bauhaus," 2019–2020

The community can get inspired by viewing the artwork of Art in Bloom. The full gallery of creative submissions can be viewed on Flickr, as well as the gallery of category winners.

Also, explore the artwork of community groups the Material Girls Quilt Guild and students of McKay Arts Academy inspired by the Art in Bloom event and the spirit of spring.

For more information, please e-mail Membership and Events Manager, Jessie Olson at events@fitchburgartmuseum.org and be sure to visit their website at www.fitchburgartmuseum.org
